div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,139] ALEXANDRIA, SATURDAY, MARCH 4, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

This most popular hotel on the Upper Nile has recently been enlarged by the addition of 65 rooms and accomodates guests. Great dining hall, lifts, tennis court and garden. div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: In the early part of yesterday we had summer weather, with a moderate breeze from the eastward. Towars sunset the barometer began to fall, the weather became cooler, and the wind veered to the south, remaining so throughout the night. The day opens dull an threatening with every indication of bad weather. Barimeter falling and low.

TUESDAY, MARCH 4, 1905.

div.head: THE RAILWAY REPORT.
div.p: The State Railways Commissioners append to their Report much detailed information as to the expenditure proposed by them and which, based on approximate figures, amounts to practically two and a quarter millions of pounds. Roughly speaking, another three quarters of a million are entered for “new lines” and we are thus brought back to the figure of three millions which has been talked of for some time as necessary for railway purposes. To us it is very satisfactory to observe that the needs of Lower Egypt in general, and of Alexandria and Gabbari in particular, are held to be the greatest and the most pressing, but, as additions and improvements find their places under all possible heads and at all parts of the system, satisfaction must be generally felt. Incidentally reference is made to the provision of four lines of rails between Cairo and Alexandria. In onr opinion, this work will prove of earlier and greater importance than some of the proposed extensions, and we think it, or our end of it, might well have found its place in a 3-year programme of expenditure. The most urgent need, and one of the largest provisions, is for "rolling stock.” Engines are said to have been kept alive too long, the necessity for which is to cease, and improved types are the capital which will secure both economy and efficiency. The theory that it is best to work an engine to death fairly quickly is a somewhat new one from the other side of the Atlantic, but it is being very generally accepted as correct all over the world. More carriages are to be supplied in view of increased passenger traffic induced by a reduction of the lowest class fares. We are ourselves inclined to think the increased facilities, even without any serious decrease of charges, will bring a large additional passenger traffic. Goods wagons are to be obtained to

meet the increased demand for them, and to prevent such traffic as properly belongs to the railways being diverted to water and other routes. The requireménts of the public are fully considered in this matter, and the details specified show that train safety, convenience, and comfort have been studied. This consideration, indeed, appears to have been carried to an extreme, and while we do not accept, as a necessity, the provision of bogie carriage-, for the lowest class traffic, we do not either under stand the affection shown for the 10 ton goods wagon.

Taken as a whole, the improvement effected of late years in the condition of the “Perina nent way” seems to have been very great, and apparently the attention devoted to this in. Lower Egypt has, to some extent, stood in the way of other requirements which will now be seen to. A great deal is to be taken in hand in respect of improved station and siding accommodation, which will facilitate the working of the traffic and make it safer. Unfortunately, from the remarks on the subjects of “Signalling” and ‘Fencing,” there is an all too present and even unnecessary danger to travellers upon the railways and to persons crossing the lines. All wants of this sort appear to have been seen and their rectification provided for to a reasonable extent. The above requirements,, and the doubling of the line from Wasta to Minieh in Upper Egypt and from Palais de Koubbeh to Matarieh on the local line out of Cairo, practically total up to the recommendation of the Commission to expend a sum of £2,224,000.

A sum of £700,000 is added for “projected lines,” but the Commissioners wisely discriminate between reporting upon open lines of railways and giving an opinion upon those projected. This they leave to those who are better acquainted with and have larger opportunities of studying the requirements and the prospective values of the districts intended to be served. Our own view is that a line from Salhieh to Kantara must kill that recently constructed between Kautara and ismailia, and the line from Zagazig to Zifta is no longer necessary in an already well served district, if, as we are compelled to, we regard Port Said as the natural outlet for the Zazazig district. We probably shall not hear much more of these new lines at present, and in the meantime we shall expect other projects to claim attention. The proposal to widen the gauge between Luxor and Assouan is set aside for what appear to be excellent reasons, including due appreciation of the fact that even a large first-class passenger traffic for a short period in the year does not, from a business point of view, justify a big outlay. In the place of this proposal one is put forward to connect the Egyptian and Sudan railways by supplying the missing link between Assouan and Wady Haifa. It is only a distance of 200 miles or so, and the recommendation of the Commissioners is doubtless based, in a general way, upon their experience that it pays to “link up” under such circumstances. We are ourselves inclined to think so in this case, if no great natural obstacles present themselves, and, in addition, we see in the project great advantage for administration and military purposes.

The different “Notes” in the Appendix contain much of interest, and to those who feel so inclined we commend a perusal thereof. The tables which give comparative working results of the Egyptian State Railways with others in India and South America, are instructive to those who can understand the conclusions and the inferences to be drawn from them. The separation of the Port of Alexandria from the Railways is a matter which may well be for the advantage of both, in leaving each administration to deal with the work for which it is best fitted. Working arrangements need in no way be disturbed, while decentralisation will more readily disclose the responsibility for defects in these. The impression clearly left upon our minds is that both the quay accommodation of the port and the wagon stock of the railways have been insufficient in the past. The railways are to be supplied with some wagons, we trust the port may be so with more quays. In the meantime the discontinuance of stacking coal thereon, the provision of lighters and cranes, etc,, may afford considerate relief.

We have left to the last our remarks upon the explanations offered by the Chairman of the Railways Administration. They are brief, pointed, and dignified. The conclusion we base upon them is that this high official does not object to the report in toto, or even in great measure, but considers that reasons, good in themselves, sufficiently explain certain defects noticed. On such a matter we cannot offer any opinion, neither are we acquainted with the system usually adopted in dealing with such inspections, but if there is a weak point in the report, which appears so admirable iu its preparation, it is that room should have been left for any explanations at all, so far as the public are concerned. Their publication, under the circumstances, is held by the Government to be right and proper. It is so by us also.

div.head: OYAMA’S ARMIES.
div.p: ENVELOPING THE RUSSIAN FLANKS.
GREAT COMBINED MOVEMENT.
TERRIFIC BOMBARDMENT.
MUKDEN SAID TO BE EVACUATED.

Tientsin, March 3. Four hundred Japanese cavalry have raided Sin-Min-Ting. There are 10,000 Japanese along the Niu-Chwang-Kao-Pan-Tse line, which it is expected the Japanese will seize on the ground that it has long since ceased to be neutral. This raid, in conjunction with the advance of the Japanese left, is considered to indicate that Oyama’s armies are enveloping the Russian Hanks while holding the centre. (Reuter.)
Mukden, March 3. The Russians have checked the Japanese turning movement. Desperate fighting is proceeding all along the line. ( Havas. )

London, March 3. The correspondents at the front indicate a great combined movement of the Japanese, which appears to be succeeding in every quarter. Four Japanese divisions can be seen 11 miles westward of Mukden, in consequence of which the Russian right appears to have been turned. A most terrific bombardment by 100 of the biggest guns is concentrated against Putiloff and Novgorod Hills on the Russian centre. The Japanese have made great gains on the Russian left by night advances. Rumours are current that Mukden has been evacuated. (Reuter.)

St. Petersburg, March 3. According to telegrams received here, the Japanese furiously assailed the Russian centre. They advanced twice to storm Putiloff hill, but twice were driven back with heavy losses. General Kuropatkin reports that he is holding the Japanese at bay and recapturing some positions from which the Russians had been driven. He asserts having inflicted enormous losses on the Japanese at several points. (R.)

div.head: NORTH SEA INDEMNITY.
div.p: AMOUNT OF BRITISH CLAIM.
London, March 3. The British claim for the North Sea indem- nity has been presented. It amounts to £65,000. (Reuter.)

div.head: IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT.
div.p: MINISTERIAL CHECK.

London, March 3. House of Commons.—During the debate on the supplementary Army and Navy Estimates, the Opposition seized the opportunity of a small Ministerial attendance to snap a division. The Government majority fell to 24, and the debate was adjourned. (Reuter.)

div.head: DEATH.
div.p: McCLENAHAN.- This morning, at her residence at the American Mission, Haret-el-Yahood, Alexandria, the wife of the Rev. W. mcClenahan. A short service wil1 be held in the Native Church at 1 .30 a.m. to-morrow, and another service will be held at the British emeter, at 12.30 p.m. Friends will lease accept as an invitation.

div.head: CONDITION OF RUSSIA.
div.p: FURTHER DISORDERS FEARED.
TSAR’S CHANGE OF FRONT

St. Petersburg, March 3 Another meeting of the workmen’s electors took place yesterday. It was decided that, unless their demands are conceded to-day, a general strike is to proclaimed. There is general apprehension here, and at Warsaw and Moscow, that disorders on a large scale will take place on Saturday, which is the anniversary of the liberation of the serfs. (Reuter.)

St. Petersburg, March 3. A manifesto of the Tsar exhorts the people to defend the Throne against foreign enemies. Another rescript appoints the Minister of the Interior to preside at the conference which is to draw up the scheme of legislative elections. (Havas.)

St. Petersburg, March 3. The group of Ministers who were engaged in drafting a Constitution have fallen into disfavour, and the reactionaries have regained the ear of the Tsar, who has issued a manifesto reaffirming the autocracy and appealing to the whole nation to unite against internal enemies, and their obstinate foreign foe. (R.)

Warsaw, March 3. The strike affects every trade here. The strikers are assuming a threatening demeanour and are using revolvers and bombs. Unless the Government can force the gasmen to resume work, the city will be in darkness on Sunday. The Tsar’s manifesto has produced a bad effect. The authorities are hastily concentrating troops at Warsaw and Lodz. (Reuter.)
LOCAL AND GENERAL.
New Year’s Day.—The Government offices and administrations will not be closed on the New Year’s Day of the Hegira next week.
Post Office Notice—New offices for correspondence and parcels have been opened at Nadir (Menoufieh) and Biltan (Galioubieh).
The New Secondary School which will probably be built at Ghizeh during the next 18 months will bear the name of “Kavalla.”
Egyptian Ivory, to the amount of 2 tons 5 cwt. 1 qr. 21 lbs., has arrived in London lor the quarterly sales on the 18th April.
Fatal Fall.—A workman employed on the roof of a house in St. Catherine’s-square yesterday accidentally fell over and was killed on the spot.
Mariout.- The barley in the Mariout district is in excellent condition, and this winter’s rains assure, to all appearance, a very first-class crop.
Suez Canal.—11 vessels passed through the Canal on the 1st inst. Of these 9 were British, 1 German, 1 Norwegian. The day’s receipts were 1rs. 359,746.03.
Bristol Hotel.—The proprietor of the Bristol Hotel at Cairo, Mr. Charles Bauer, has taken a lease of the hotel from the landlord, and intends greatly improving the hotel.
All Saints’ Church.—The Right Rev. Bishop Brent, Bishop of the Philippine Islands, U.S.A., will preach at All Saint’s Church, Cairo, on Sunday morning next. Service begins at 10.30 a.m.

“Eastern Egypt Company.”—Such, it is said, is to be the title of a new company in course of formation in Cairo by the Eid group, which will concern itself with land and other operations in the Gharbieh Province.
Bourse Suicide.—Yesterday Mr. Rubba, a “remisier” on the Alexandria Bourse in the employ of Messrs. Frangi and Co., blew his brains out with a revolver in consequence of financial trouble.
Alexandria Antiquities.—The number of visitors to the Museum during February totalled 1,372, of whom 1,042 were admitted tree. 377 persons visited “Pompey’s Pillar,” and 564 Kom-el-Shougafa.
Alexandria Harbour.—The Government has opened a credit of L.E. 1,000 with the Railway Administration to cover the expenses of plans, etc., with a view to completing the quay system at Alexandria.

Hudson’s Bay Company—Private telegrams received to-day at Alexandria state that the Americans are buying Hudson’s Bay Company’s stock in immense quantities. The price on Thursday was £70-72 and yesterday £73 1/4.

National Bank.—The Caisse de la Dette has consigned L.E. 182,000 to the National Bank of Egypt this week. This sum represents the economies resulting to the Government in virtue of the Anglo-French Convention.

Naval Contract.—Admiral Sir Compton Domville, Commander-in Chief in the Mediterranean, has awarded Messrs. E. Barber and Son the contract for the supply of fresh provisions and water to H.M. ships at Alexandria for all items.

Italian Benevolent society.—The ball in the Esbekieh Gardens, given last night by the Italian Benevolent Society of Cairo; was in every way a great success, and dancing continued with great animation until an early hour this morning.

Alhambra Theatre.—The programme for the Alhambra to-night is one of the most attractive that has been presented for some time. A matinée performance will be given to-morrow and also on Shrove Tuesday. There will be a ball to-night and to-morrow night.

Alexandria Horticultural Society. — Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel has given an annual prize of an “objet d’art” to the value of £20 to be presented by the Alexandria Horticultural Society. This year it will be given for the best collection of 24 roses and next year for 40 pots of show pelargoniums.

Coal Imports.—From the 1st of January to the 2nd of March 95,568 tons were imported into Egypt as against 164,538 tons during the corresponding period of 1904. Newcastle sent 18,584 tons, the Welsh districts 56,732, the Scotch districts 10,322, Yorkshire 7,806, and other districts 2,124 tons.

Property at Ghezireh.—Aoting on behalf of Col. Frank Rhodes, Messrs. Reid and Barnard have sold a property in Ghezireh Palace Gardens acquired by him in 1901 at a price of P.T. 250 per metre, a figure which constitutes a new record for land at Ghezireh. The buyers are understood to be Messrs. J. Hog and Co.

Marsa Matrouh.—With reference to the notice recently issued by the Government to the effect that no further applications for land in the neighbourhood of Marsa Matrouh will be entertained, we may mention that the only concession granted so far has been one of 10,000 feddans to the Marsa Matrouh Syndicate.

Mena House.—The small dance held at Mena on Wednesday was very successful. Dancing was kept up with great spirit until midnight. The next small dance will be held on Wednesday, 15th inst., and the next and last Gymkhana of this season on Friday, 24th inst., at 3 p.m. On Saturday night, 18th inst., a Venetian night fête will be held at Mena.

Oriental Carpets.—Messrs. T. A. Spartali & Co. have decided to keep open their exhibition of Oriental carpets in Old Bourse-street, Alexandria, until the 17th inst. owing to the demands of their numerous clientèle. Mr. Fritz Balladur, their representative, will remain at Alexandria until that date to take orders for next season, and has a number of designs with him. Clients are requested to make an appointment with him at their houses. After the 17th inst. all applications should be made to their Cairo office, opposite the Savoy Hotel.

New Hotel in Cairo.—Mr. C. Aquilina, proprietor of the Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley, and general manager of the Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan, is in treaty with a local capitalist to build a first-class hotel, of about 100 bedrooms, in a prominent position on the new quay at Alexandria, which would be kept open all the year round. If the scheme is realised, it will no doubt prove a great boon to both visitors and residents, for at present there is ample room for another up-to-date hotel-in Alexandria, and under the personal management of Mr. Aquilina its success will be assured.

Egypt and the Russian Fleet. — A correspondent of the “Pall Mall Gazette,” after reviewing the arguments contained in Mr. Mcllwraith’s recent letter to the “Times,” remarks, “In offering an explanation for the facilities offered to the Baltic Fleet, the Judicial Adviser has rather done the opposite of what he intended, and his argument leads one to infer that there was a slight error of judgment in the 1898 incident, and that the letter to the ‘Times’ was a very ingenious attempt at throwing the onus of it on to Sir Julian Pauncefote’s reservation to the Suez Canal Convention.”

Merchant Seamen’s Home. — The usual weekly concert was held in the Seamen’s Home last night, when there was a good audience and a very interesting programme was presented. The artistes were Messrs. Tulloch, Allit, and Fordan, and the Messrs. Tookey, from Bulkeley, who generously gave their services for the evening. The Messrs. Tookey set themselves especially to entertain the audience, and from the vociferous applause their various songs provoked it was evident that they were highly successful. Frequent encores were enthusiastically demanded, and they were as heartily conceded. A place was found for the gramophone on the programme, and for a real good hearty concert last night’s entertainment would be hard to beat. The Rev. H. P. Reid presided and Mr. Wm, Wood acted as accompanist.

div.head: ENGLISH PENSION ITALIAN RIVIERA.
div.p: The best halfway house between Egypt and England is VIAREGGIO. near PISA.
Main line expresses stop. Pine woods, Sands, Sea bathing, mild climate, English Pension, Villa Shelley. Every home comfort. Electric light. Modern sanitation, Sunny aspect, close to sea and gardens.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION.
div.p: MOSLEM NEW YEAR’S DAY.
On the occasion of the Mohammedan New Year’s Day, the Khedive will hold a reception at Abdeen Palace on Tuesday next, when visitors will be received in the following order :—
At 8.30 a.m. The Ulemah ; the General Assembly and Legislative Council ; the Governor of Cairo and the Moudir of Ghizeh, the officers of the Army and Navy, from the rank of Bimbashi upwards.

At 9 a.m. The officials of the following administrations : Council of Ministers, Ministry of the Interior, Board of Health, Prisons Inspectorate, Slave Trade Repression Department, Cairo Gouvernorat, Ghizeh Moudirieh, Finance Ministry, Postal Administration, the Coast Guards, Public Debt Commission, Daira Sanieh, State Domains Administration, Administration of Railways, Telegraphs and the Port of Alexandria, Public Works Ministry, Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Public Instruction, Ministry of War, Foreign Office, Wakfs Administration.

At 9.30 a.m. The Princes of the Khedivial Family ; the President of the Council of Ministers and the Ministers ; the Financial Adviser and the Adviser at the Ministry of the Interior and of Public Works ; the Under Secretaries of State.

At 10 a.m. The former Presidents of the Council of Ministers, the former Ministers, Presidents of the Legislative Council, Sirdars, Grand Masters of Ceremonies, heads of the Khedivial Cabinet, chief Aides-de-Camp, Directors of the Khédivial Khassa, Directors General of Wakfs, Under Secretaries of State ; Directors-General of the Daira Sanieh, administrators of the State Domains and administrators of the Railways, Telegraphs, and Port of Alexandria ; unofficial military and civil personages having the rank of Lewa or Oula Sinf Sani and upwards, the officers of the Army and Navy unattached and on the retired list having the rank of Kaimakam or Miralai ; the unofficial civil Beys, having the rank of Moutemaiz or Sanieh and upwards.
At 10.30 a.m. The Diplomatic and Consular Corps.

At 10.45 a.m. The Directors-Commissioners of the Public Debt Commission ; the Director General and the Controllers of the Daira Sanieh ; the State Domains administrators ; the administrators of Railways, Telegraphs, and the Port of Alexandria.
At 11.15-a.m. The field officers of the Army of Occupation ; the clergy ; the Mixed Magistracy ; the Native Magistracy.
At 11.45 a.m. The Khedivial Counsellors ; native notables ; European notables ; the officials of the military and civil households of H.H. the Khedive and those of the Khédivial Khassa.
This reception is reserved to persons resident in Cairo.
The military will be in undress uniform and civilians will wear frock coats (redingote).

The civil officials admitted to this reception are those having at least the rank of sub-director or an equivalent rank, and those having at least the grade of Sanieh or that of Kaimakam, and magistrates appointed by decree.

The Khedivah will also hold a reception on Tuesday at Koubbeh Palace. The Princesses of the Khédivial Family and native ladies will be received from 9 to 11.30 a.m., European ladies from 3.30 to 4.15 p.m., and the wives of members of the Diplomatic Corps at 4.20 p.m.
THE KHEDIVE.
The Khedive will leave Cairo on Thursday next for Montazah and will leave Alexandria soon afterwards for a fortnight’s excursion into the Libyan desert.
STATE RAILWAYS.

We are authorised to state that the Egyptian Government has no intention of bringing out a new general manager for the State Railways from England or elsewhere. Major L’Es-trange Johnstone will retain his functions as head of the railways.
DELTA LIGHT RAILWAYS.
At its sitting of Monday next, the Council of Ministers will approve of the issue of 39,000 new shares of L.E. 10 by the Egyptian Delta Light Railway Company, Ltd.
EGYPTIAN ESTATES, LIMITED.

The abridged prospectus of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, will be found on page 4 of to-day’s issue. An examination of the prospectus shows that the company is to be constituted on a sound basis, and there is every prospect that it will attract investors both at home and in this country. The board of directors and the advisory board are very strong in men connected with large and successful enterprises in Egypt.
P. & O. COMPANY.

We are desired to state that the P. & 0. Company’s main line steamers to Marseilles regularly leave Port Said at 5 p.m. every Monday after the arrival of the 11 o'clock morning train from Cairo, and a steam tender awaits the train to convey passengers on board. 25518-12-2
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Cunard S.S. “Cypria” arrived on Thursday at Liverpool. She experienced very bad weather on her way home.
The S.S. “Carib Prince” left Manchester on the 2nd inst. with passengers and general cargo for Malta and Alexandria,

div.head: GARRISON CHANGES.
div.p: DEPARTURE OF ARTILLERY.

The hired transport “Dilwara” arrived at Alexandria from Southampton and Malta this morning with details for the Army of Occupation, including four companies of the 1st Battalion King’s Royal Rifle Corps and headquarters. The troops were disembarked at once, and left for Cairo by special train from Gabbari at 11 o’clock. They will arrive in Cairo about 5.40 p.m. and will proceed to Abbassieh.

The 56th Battery Royal Field Artillery left Cairo at 9.15 a.m. to day and arrived at Gab bari at half-past one. Their embarkation on the transport for conveyance home was proceeding as we went to press.
The company of the Royal Malta Artillery which has been stationed at Fort Kom el-Dik for the last 5 years, also embarked on the “Dilwara” for passage to Malta.
The “Dilwara” sails for Malta this evening.
The following Special General Order was issued yesterday :—

The G.O.C. does not wish the 5th Company Royal Malta Artillery to leave his Command without expressing his satisfaction at the creditable manner in which their duties have been carried out during their tour of service in Egypt.

Their conduct has been excellent ; their professional work has been extremely well done; whilst the general efficiency and skill-at-arms reflect great credit on Major Balbi and all ranks in the Company.
In bidding them farewell the G.O.C. wishes them every success and a hearty welcome on their return home.
SEASONABLE CANARDS.

Nothing whatever is known at the British and German Agencies of the rumoured visits of H.M. the King or H.I.M. the German Emperor to Egypt in the near future. Rumours have been more circumstantial this year than usual, but we have noticed that “canards” of the kind generally fly about at this time of the year.
THE PILGRIMAGE.
The Khédivial Co.’s S.S. “Minieh,” the first ship to bring back the returning pilgrims, left Jeddah yesterday for Tor and Constantinople.
Owing to the cool weather, and the good state of public health prevailing at the Holy Places, the pilgrims are delaying their return home.
COAST GUARD SEIZURE.

The following contraband was seized on board the Italian S.S. “Armonia” yesterday afternoon by the Coast Guards :—2 revolvers, 2 breech loading rifles, 281 revolver cartridges, 50 rifle cartridges, 290 cartridges (various kinds), 20 rockets, 1,159 Havana cigars, and 19 kilos tobacco.
A. L. M. & D. S.

The concert given at the New Khedivial Hotel on Wednesday evening was a great artistic success, and was thoroughly enjoyed by the large number of members present. The programme was extremely well chosen, if too classical for the majority of those present, containing as it did such names as Mme Briend, Mme Haddad, Dr. Keller, and Mr. Afendoulis. Mme Briend, who is the wife of the Inspector-General of the Quarantine Board, contributed three numbers, Air de Chimène, from Massenet’s Le Cid,“L’Attente” (Saint Saëns), and “Si mes vers avaient des ailes” (Reynald Halhn), besides singing the duet “Près aux Clercs” with Dr. Keller. In each Mme Briend was magnificent, and enthralled her hearers by her exquisite singing. Mme. Haddad, whose mastery over the pianoforte is well-known, gave an Impromptu by Rubinstein and “Le Rossignol” by Liszt in the first part, and Liszt’s “Rhapsodie Hongroise No. 12” in the second part. All three pieces were given with that perfect execution which distinguishes Mme. Haddad’s playing, and called forth the sincere appreciation of the audience. Mr. Afendoulis, the famous Greek violinist, who took the first prize at the Brussels Conservatoire a few years ago, has not been heard of late and was warmly welcomed, Notwithstanding his being severely handicapped by having lost his usual accompanist, Mme Foscolo, through influenza, he delighted and astonished everyone by his performance of Tirindelli’s Airs Hongrois and in the second part received a hearty encore for his two pieces by Simonetti and Scambati. Dr. Keller, besides singing in the very beautiful duet by Auber with Mme Briend, sang two solos, and his fine voice was shown to great advantage in Mario Costa’s Serenata. The Choral Union, who had only received their part music from London a fortnight before the concert, sang a glee, a madrigal, and two part songs. They appeared a little nervous in the first number, but gradually gained greater confidence and did best in Schumann’s “Gipsy Life.” We hope to hear more from this youngest branch of the A.L.M. & D.S. and that next time they will be able to get their music by heart, which adds immensely to the decision and ensemble of choral singing. Great credit is due to their conductor, Mr. Sarjeant, whose energy and enthusiasm would fire any chorus to excel itself. The accompanist, Mrs. Crafton, deserves sincere thanks for her excellent playing and indefatigable pains in working with the Choral Union.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H. R. H. the Duke of. Connaught has presented H. E. the Governor with an autograph portrait of himself.

H. R. H. Prince Gustavus Adolphus, of Sweden and Norway, who left for Athena yesterday, is leaving the Piræus for Constantinople on the 10th inst by the Khédivial Mail liner “Ismailia,” which sails from Alexandria on Wednesday afternoon next for the Piræus ( Athens ), Smyrna, Mitylene, and Constantinople.
The Earl and Countess of Londesborough and Lord George Cholmondeley have arrived at Mena House, where they intend to stay for a week.
Lord E. Cecil Pasha, Agent General of the Sudan Government, has gone home on three 'months’ leave. His duties will in his absence be undertaken by Miralai Matchett Bey.
Boghos Pasha Nubar, in lieu of sending a wreath on the occasion of the death of Haicalis Pasha, sent, L.E. 4 to the Rudolph Home at Alexandria.
M. Maspero is expected to return to Cairo on the 16th inst from Upper Egypt and will leave in the third week of the month for Athens to represent the Government at the Archeological Congress.

Maitre Albrecht, who after returning to consciousness, suffered very severe pain from his injuries, is now progressing very favorably under Dr. Milton’s skilled hands. We regret to hear that from the condition of the patient’s left eye permanent injury to the sight is highly probable.
Mr. Coote, the well-known secretary of the London Vigilance Society, is arriving at Alexandria to-morrow to investigate the conditions of the white slave traffic prevailing here.

GUM ARABIC.

London, February 24. Gum Arabic has been very quiet, Bombay descriptions being almost inactive. Sudan Sorts are lower, good qualities being offered at 21s 6d to 22s, but no sales are reported. 35 bales sold in the Drug sales yesterday, without reserve at 24s to 25s for good quality. The market has been practically cleared of ordinary sorts of Persian, and there is still a Good Shiraz has been placed at full values.

div.head: ABRIDGED PROSPECTUS.
div.p: This Company is formed for the purposes set out in its Memorandum of Association, and in particular to conduct business in Egypt and the Soudan, as opportunity affords, and more particularly :-
To purchase, lease, hire and secure concessions of land either in town or country.
To reclaim, improve, cultivate, develop, lease, or otherwise deal with Properties when acquired.
To develop building land by the erection of houses or otherwise.
To advance money on mortgage or otherwise, to acquire mortgage or other securities either individually or jointly with others.
To carry on any business which may be profitably or conveniently worked in connection with any of the foregoing enterprises.

Egypt presents a large field for profitable employment of money in lending on safe mortgage. The gross value of land in Egypt is put by experts at £300,000,000, an average value of £50 per feddan on 6,000,000 feddans.

The advance in prosperity of the country owing to British Administration, the Anglo-French Agreement, and the recent proposed official introduction of the English language into the Mixed Tribunals is well known. The value of land in Egypt for agricultural and building purposes is shewn by innumerable sales and re-sales at constantly enhanced prices, and by the market quotation of Land Companies operating in Egypt, and it is believed that opportunities will occur of securing land which should greatly increase in value within a short space of time.

Owing to the increase in the population of the larger towns of Egypt, there is a very healthy and steady demand for well-built houses, and in the purchase, development and re-sale of estates for residential and other purpose, ample scope for remunerative business is afforded ; it is considered that from this source the Company should derive a fair income.

The opening of Government lands in the Soudan should not only afford favourable opportunity for investing large Capital amounts on mortage for many years to come, but also offer favourable opportunities for purchase and development. The conversion of basin land to canalised summer cultivation in Middle Egypt, the regular reclamation and improvement of salt land in Lower Egypt offer additional occasion for profitable business.

The Climate of Egypt is such, and the richness of the soil is so great, that crops can be grown continuously, the land not requiring to lie fallow. The land in Lower Egypt grows a winter crop of beans, wheat, barley, clover, &c., and again a summer crop of,cotton rice or maize, besides minor crops of numerous kinds of vegetables. The chief products are cotton, wheat, maize, barley, rice, beans, lentils, peas, rape, lettuce, mustard, saffron, capsicum, aniseed, sugar cane, figs, dates, oranges, lemons, melons, mandarins, limes, &c., &c.
The Articles of Association provide as follows :—

As remuneration for his services as a Director, the Chairman shall receive rémunération at the rate of £250 per annum, and the other Directors shall each receive remuneration at the rate ot £200 per annum. In addition to the said fixed rémunération there shall be divided between the Directors in such manner as they may determine a sum equal to 10 per cent, on the profits certified by the Auditors of the Company to have been made in each year in excess of a sum sufficient to provide a dividend of 7 per cent, upon the amount paid up or credited as paid up on the Ordinary Shares for the time being, having regard to the provisions as to thé division of profits herein before contained, but without making any provision for a Reserve Fund. The Directors for the time being may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to be the Managing Director or Managing Directors of the Company, either for a fixed term or without any limitation as to the period for which he or they is or are to hold such office, and may from time to time remove or dismiss him or them from office and appoint anohter or others in his or their place or places. The remuneration of a Managing Director or a Director or Director acting as managers shall from time to time be fixed by the Directors, and may be by way of salary or commission or participation in profits, or by any or/and all of these modes. If any Director, being willing, shall be called upon to perform extra service, or to make any special exertions in going or residing abroad, or otherwise, for any of the purposes of the Company, or act as Trustee for the Company or its Debenture Holders, and shall do so, the Company may remunerate such Director, either by a fixed sum or by a percentage of profits, or otherwise, as may be determined by the Directors, and such remuneration may be either in addition to or in substitution for his remuneration above provided.

Applications for Shares should be made on the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company’s Bankers. If no allotment is made, the Application money will be returned in full, and where the number of Shares allotted is less than that applied for the surplus will be credited in reduction of the amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to the Applicant.
Failure to pay any instalment when due will render the previous payments liable to be forfeited.

A copy of the Memorandum of Association, with names, addresses and descriptions of the Signatories thereof and the number of Shares subscribed for by them respectively will be found in the fold of the Prospectus, of which it forms part.
The minimum subscription upon which the Directors may proceed to Allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association at £100,000.

The estimated preliminary expenses of the Company, including registration fees and advertising and issuing this Prospectus in this country and in Egypt, and all other expenses, except brokerage on application for shares, and Stamps on Share Warrants, amounts to six thousand pounds; and in relation thereto a Contract dated the 22nd day of Feburary, 1905 has been made between George Hamilton Craig, of the one part, and Sydney William Bartman, as Trustee for the Company, of the other part, whereby the Company, agrees to pay six thousand pounds for such preliminary expenses, the said George Hamilton Craig being entitled to retain any difference between the preliminary expenses and six thousand pounds, and undertaking to pay any sum by which the estimate shall fall short.
A brokeage Sixpence per Share will be paid to Brokers and Bankers on all Shares applied for and alloted to the public on Application Forms bearing their stamps.
Application will be made to the Committee of the London Stock Exchange in due course for a settlement and quotation of the Company's Shares.
Print of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company, and copy of the above-mentioned Contract, can be inspected at the office of the Solicitors to the Company.
Copies of this Prospectus and Application Forms can be obtained at the Offices of the Company, the Bankers and Solicitors.
Dated London, 25th February, 1905.

div.head: EGYPT AND SUDAN MINING CAPITAL INCREASE
div.p: The report for the year to September 30 states that there is a not profit of £84,460. The direc-tors recommend a dividend of 5s. per share in cash, or £13,125, and a distribution of 39,375 fully-paid shares of the Sudan Gold Field ( Li-mited). The shares will be distributed in the proportion of three Sudan shares for every four Syndicate shares. Proposals have recently been submitted to the directors in regard to two properties in the Sudan, in connection with which, after very careful consideration, they have entered into provisional arrangements whereby this Syndicate will, in the event of the preliminary inspection proving satisfactory, acquire further options for dealing with the areas. The directors recommend that the capital be increased from £52,500 to £80,000 by creation of 27,500 shares of £1 each, to be offered, in the first instance, to the shareholders at the price of £1 10s. The issued would be in the proportion of one new share for every two shares now held, leaving a balance of 1,250 shares for which applications would be entertained independently of the proportionate allotments.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN INDIA
div.p: THE SINDH EXPERIMENTS.

“Indian Engineering” remarks : Every reported improvement in Indian cotton produce, if correct, means a step in the right direction, and from this limited standpoint the reported improvement, by which a profit of Rs. 200 per acre is declared to be possible from produce costing Rs. 50 per acre and saleable at Rs. 250, takes its place as part ot the fulfilment of a great hope. But what the country demands, in the place of these spasmo-dic, if valuable enough, efforts, is information whether this improvement from imported Egyptian seed is methodical or partly accidental, the result only of the new seed or of that and con-tributary experiments in soil; and if the latter, what these exactly were, and why they were restricted to Sindh, when soil like that of Sindh abounds in fifty other localities in India. The time has come when the need of some gigantic development of Indian exports has become indispensable to the placing of Indian finance on a sound basis ; and at a time when the great problem of economic develop -ment, by an intelligent control of commerce, has been subordinated to some small official game of readjusting the bundles of existing departments, and increasing mere official appointments at great cost, it is quite seasonable to insist that larger views should find expression in departmental action, and show some result for the money being spent. No one will grudge the expenditure, if large, results follow.

div.head: HOMEWARD STEAMER SAILINGS.
div.p: In reference to a paragraph which appeared in oar issue of the 1st inst. relating to the sailings of the North German Lloyd steamers, Messrs. Haselden & Co., agents for the P. &O. Company in Alexandria, request us to remove the erroneous impression that might be conveyed by the statement contained therein to the effect that “visitors need no longer wai t for steamers arriving at Port Said from the Far East at irregular intervals to take them home. Messrs. Haselden add that the P. & Co.’s main line steamers to Marseilles leave Port Said regularly at 5 p.m. every Monday after the arrival of the 11 o’clock morning train from Cairo, and a steam tender awaits the train to convey the passengers on board. We may state, however, that in making the statement we did we only referred to the steamers of the North German Lloyd Company, which, in cousequence of the long voyages which they make from Eastern Asia and Australia, arrive at Port Said at irregular intervals. It is patrons of this company’s vessels who will appreciate the new regular service from Alexandria.

div.head: UNDER THE MOSQUITO NET
div.p: "As I laye a-thinkynye.” Ingoldsby.

Never make rash promises ! Last week I ended my notes by saying that I would return to the subject on which I was writing, this week. But in the meantime a friend has lent me his “Commonplace Book” and I have found so much in it of anything but a commonplace nature, that I want while I have the opportunity to cull a few of these gems of thought, and place them before readers of the "Gazette."

But a promise is a promise, and should always be kept, unless really urgent reasons and m the way of its fulfilment. Many a promise is made only to be forgotten, while I am afraid still more are made without the slightest intention on the part of the persons making them of keeping them, and cause much of the bitterness of life that we all more or less experience.

Few, too, stop to consider the disappointment felt by children when promises—made to them, perhaps, to dry their tears, perhaps to console them for the non-fulfilment of previous promises, or for many other reasons—are not kept. Poor little things they often have to become initiated in the ways of the world at a very early age and practical lessons such as these are not lost upon them, but in their turn bear fruit.
So the world wags on.—And so I go wandering on, as I pen the thoughts that come to me under the mosquito net. But now revenons à nos moutons.

Last week I quoted a, passage from Sir Howard Vincent’s address on the Suez Canal, —a passage in which he very happily hit off England’s true relationship to Egypt. There are other passages in this most admirable and lucid sketch of the history of the Canal, that I should be only too glad to think were fully borne out by facts. Optimistic as I am myself as to the present condition and future prospects of this country, I know enough to make me hesitate to commit myself to all the statements made by Sir Howard.

“How nobly it (i.e. British influence) has been exercised for the good of the Egyptian people, under the auspices of Lord Cromer and his assistants, only those can appreciate who knew the Egypt of 30, 25, and 20 years ago, and know the Egypt of to-day.” Probably it would be difficult to find the man who would call in question the truth of this statement.

“Life and property are absolutely safe from one end of the country to the other.” This I think would be a bold statement to make, even as regards England itself, but substitute “comparatively” for “absolutely,” and few would dispute the correctness of the assertion. One of the contrasts between England and Egypt that struck me most forcibly on my arrival in this country, was that while in London the windows of jewellers’ shops are generally after dark —and sometimes by daylight—protected by iron railings, in the most brilliantly lit streets, here in Cairo and Alexandria they remain quite unguarded, even in such a dimly lit thoroughfare as the Sharia Kasr el Nil is (or was two years ago). I used to reflect that it was quite as well that the fact was not known to the London thieves, who, were they aware of it, might perhaps be tempted to take advantage of such opportunities for the exercise of their predatory operations.

“ There is equal justice for all.” ‘ No hardships and no tyranny.” Why, if these statements are true Egypt must be a sort of pars, dise,— a real Utopia! Surely Lord Cromer’s work here is done, and he is more wanted in England than in Egypt ! But I fancy that his lordship would shake his head, and opine that the gallant Colonel was just a leetle out in his calculations, and should have come a little further than the Canal to ascertain the truth on these points. No ! This ideal has yet to be realised.

“The resources, of science have converted desert wastes into fertile plains.” The only fault I find in this sentence is that it wants supplementing by another to the effect that, far from this work being finished, much has to be done before the full benefits of even the already partially completed works can be enjoyed.

There are one or two other statements that might be challenged and which to say the least are premature, but no exception can be taken to Sir Howard’s concluding words on the results of the British occupation of Egypt, and they emphasise a fact that is too often lost sight of, and too little brought prominently forward, by those who are best qualified to testify to its absolute truth.
“As the Englishman passes up the great waterway of the Nile, or over the crowded

railways, and sees the luxuriant crops, the industrious peasants, and their multitude of animals tethered on the luxuriant pastures, he may well feel pride in the work, civil and military of his countrymen, and rejoice that in H.H. Khedive Abbas II. they have an illustrious fellow-worker, whose delight it is to convert poor lands into rich, and by agricultural virtues to repair the once shattered fortunes of his House.”

All this I steadfastly believe. Bat may I ask the gallant Colonel one question ? What, are “agricultural virtues” ? Agricultural pursuits I could understand, but virtues! Well, well, we ail make slips and occasionally get our tongues into tangles, and one need not be hypercritical on so admirably expressed (this slight blemish excepted) a description of the picture presented by the Egypt of to-day.

To understand a little as to the work that remains to be done in Egypt the reader has only to refer to the paper on “The Nile Fens,” by D. G. Hogarth, the first part of which appeared in the “Gazette” yesterday. This is a delicious bit of writing too, and should But be missed by readers with an imaginative turn of mind.

I have not much space left for referring to the Commonplace Book, on the contents of which I should never tire to dwell. For it is veritable thought-provoker, and also a good index to the mind ot the compiler. In this respect it is incomparably superior to a diary, the entries in which must be greatly determined by physical conditions.

But here you see at once the food that the mind-the real man-enjoys, and although the most opposite opinions on important questions find places, the key to the whole is not only the subject selectedm but the appreciation of the way in which it is presented by the author.
Here is a charming hit of Tennyson :— Thou canst not prove that thou art body [alone,
Nor canst thou prove that thou art spirit alone, Nor canst thou prove that thou art both in [one:
Thou canst not prove thou art immortal, no, Nor yet that thou art mortal—nay my son, Thou canst not prove that I, who speak with [thee,

Am not thyself in converse with thyself, For nothing worthy proving can be proven Nor yet disproven : wherefore thou be wise, Cleave ever to the sunnier side of doubt, And cling to Faith beyond the forms of Faith !”

I thought of underlining some of the above, but if I once commenced, it seems to me that I should have to underline it all. I commend the whole quotation to the consideration of the good people whose minds have lately been somewhat exercised over various matters that I have dealt with in this column. T. A.

div.head: ISMAILIA MOSQUITOES.
div.p: The “Vérité” of Port-Said remarks :
On sait que, dans le temps, la Compagnie du Canal de Suez avait chargé un spécialiste, le major Ross, d’étudier le moyen de détruire les moustiques à Ismaïlia.

Le major Ross avait trouvé que le pétrole était le seul remède à employer pour débarrasser la ville de ces parasites. Le remède préconisé par ce spécialiste a été d’autant plus efficace que dans la ville d’ismaïlia les moustiques ont complètement disparu.

La Compagnie du Canal, soucieuse de la santé publique, pour détruire les insectes nuisibles et preserver les plantations, a Couvert les rues de la dite ville avec les résidus de l’usine à gaz. Ce procédé est, parait-il, très efficace.

Les habitants d’Ismailia se plaignent de la mauvaise odeur qu’exalent les rues du fait de cette innovation ; ils devraient, au contraire, applaudir à l’excellente mesure que vient de prendre la Compagnie du Canal, qui les préservera de beaucoup de maladies.

div.head: THE COPTIC TONGUE.
div.p: On the completion, this spring, of his Catalogue of the Coptic MSS. in the British Museum, Mr. W. E. Crum has undertaken to prepare a dictionary of that language, upon a scale considerably larger than any hitherto realized. In the seventy years which have passed since the appearance of Amedeo Pey-ron’s ‘Lexicon,’ the material, both published and available in MS., has very greatly increased, as has, to a still higher degree, our knowledge of the foregoing periods of the Egyptian language. It should therefore be possible today to till a want of which all Egyptian philologists are conscious, in a manner more adequate to their requirements than was attainable in Peyron’s time. There is reason to hope that the Clarendon Press may undertake the publication of the work.

div.head: FREEMASONRY IN CAIRO.
div.p: CONSECRATION OF A NEW LODGE.

A Masonic correspondent writes : — As previously notified in your columns, the Masonic event of the week was to be the consecration of the “Rising Sun” Lodge of Cairo, No. 91, working in English, under the National Grand Lodge of Egypt. This important and imposing ceremony was carried out on Monday evening, last in the splendid temple of the Grand Lodge in Sharia Boulac. His Excellency the Grand Master of Egypt Idris Beÿ Ragheb deputed Wor. Bro. Fred. A. Beale, P.M., P.G. Arch., 30°, &c., to perform the necessary ceremony, which was carried out with due solemnity. W. Bro. R.R. Smithard, P.M.,P.G.D„ &c,, as Grand Director of Ceremonies, duly formed a procession of the members present iu the ante-room and they were marched into the temple, where the consecrating officer was received in due form. W. Bros. T. M. Chinn and W. R. Johnson acted as S. W. and J. W. respectively, whilst W. Bro. P. Plunkett, Gd. S.D., acted as Secretary, with W. Bro. McIntosh as I. G.

The lodge was duly opened in the three degrees when the D. of C. formed the petitioners up in their proper places whilst the order authorising the consecration was read, the brethren standing to order. The petition was read and the petitioners assented to the officers named therein as being the first officers of the new lodge.

The ceremony of consecration was next proceeded with, and was carried out in a most satisfactory manner. The vessels containing the corn, wine, oil, salt, and the censor, were very kindly lent by W. Bro. A. Hanauer, those of the Grand Lodge being in use in the provinces, where a new lodge in Arabic was being consecrated.

At the conclusion of the ceremony, at which the following brethren assisted, W. Bros. G. Sierra, Phillips, Chinn, Smithard, McIntosh, Johnson, Lumsden, Foster-Smith, Plunkett, and King, the Worshipful Master designate, the installation was proceeded with.
Wor. Bro. W. J. King was presented by W. Bro. R. R. Smithard, the D. of C., for the benefit of Installation, which had been ordered to be carried out by W. Bro. Beale, P.M., etc.

The W. M. designate, having assented to the antient charges and regulations of the National Grand Lodge of Egypt, was duly installed as the first Wor. Master of this lodge, thus adding still another English-speaking lodge to the already long roll of those working under the banner of the National Grand Lodge of Egypt.

The newly-installed W. M. appointed his officers as follows, and duly invested them, they being conducted to their respective positions and saluted: W. Bro. Fred. A. Beale, I. P. M. and I. G. ; Bro. A. T. Roche, S. W. (proxy W. Bro. W. R. Johnson, P. M. Bulwer Lodge No. 1068.), Bro. A. G. Harris, J. W. ; Bro. A. B. Brewster Bey, treasurer; Bro. W. J. Wright, secretary ; W. Bros. R. R. Smithard and Fred. Phillips, S. D. and J. D. respectively ; W. Bro. P. Plunkett, D. of G.; W. Bro. Ahmed Bey Nasrat, organist ; Bro. A. Burnett-Collins, steward.

The Very Wor. Bro. Rev. F. B. N. Norman-Lee, P. G. Chap. Eng., Chap, to H. M. Forces, was appointed chaplain, but owing to a previous engagement was not able to attend to be invested. This will be carried out at the next meeting.

The newly-installed W. M. was duly proclaimed as such, and the usual addresses were delivered, on the conclusion of which he said his first and most pleasant duty was to tender his personal thanks to the consecrating and installing officer, and expressed the great pride he felt in having been chosen to occupy the first chair of the “Rising Sun” Lodge. The next duty which he felt proud to perform, was that of proposing the names of his Excellency the Grand Master, Idris Bey Ragheb, and his Excellency Rt. Wor. Bro. Michel Bey Saleh, Grand Secretary, as honorary life members, which was carried with acclamation.

Good wishes were received on behalf of the M.W. the Grand Master, who was unable to attend on account of not yet being out of the doctor’s hands, from the District Grand Lodge of Egypt and the Soudan, from Lodges Nos. 43, 51, 66, 74 and 83, Egyptian Constitution, 582, 1068, 1696, 2695, and 2444, English Constitution, 146 and 266 Irish Constitution, 400 and 439 Scotch Constitution.

We noticed amongst the visitors present Bros. Moores, Latailla, James, Poole, Paschel, Albu Caly, Delbourgo, etc., etc. The following additional names were subscribed to the petition before it was submitted to the Most Wor. Grand Master:—W. Bro. A. C. Garofallo, Asst. Grand Secretary, W. Bro. A. Burnett Collins, and Bro. Zossenheim of the Doric Lodge, English Constitution.
The ceremony being concluded the lodge was duly closed and the brethren adjourned to the Grand Continental Hotel, where Bro. Klingler had provided for the wants of the “inuer man.”

It may be of interest to your readers to know that the spread of Freemasonry has been so great, and is so steadily increasing, that i t is in contemplation to found other- English-speaking lodges, both in Lower and Upper Egypt. We may mention Tantah and Assiout as the first two that will receive attention

We are glad to see that the old-time ideas of an interchange of visits amongst the members of the fraternity to their lodges, no matter in what language they may be working or what their nationality, are gradually increasing, and we find that visits are frequently exchanged amongst English speaking Masonic and other Lodges under the G. L, of Egypt, no matter what the nationality of the members. We know that Freemasonry is universal, irrespective of nation ality, colour or position in the world, and it is satisfactory to learn that the spread of Masonry is to a great extent answerable for the strengthening of those ties which are inseparable from the well-being of the oldest end most world-renowned - association whoso motto is Brotherly Love, Relief and Truth.

div.head: CAUGHT BY THE GRIP. RELEASED BY PE-RU-NA.
div.p: "The world of medicine recognize Grip as epidemic catarrh."- Medical Talk.

LA GRIPPE Is epidemic catarrh. It spares no class or nationally. The cultured and the ignorant, the aristocrat and the pauper, the masses and the classes are alike subject to la grippe. None are exempt—all are liable.

Have you the grip? Or, rather, has the grip got you? Grip is well named. The original French term, la grippe, has been shortened by the busy American to read “grip.” Without intending to do so a new word has been coined that exactly describes the case. As if some hideous giant with awful Grip had clutched us In its fatal clasp. Men, women, children, whole towns and cities are caught in the baneful grip of a terrible monster.

div.head: KARNAK.
div.p: M. Legrain has published a summary of the results of his work at Karnak in 1903. new discoveries include a representation in has relief of the wars of Amenophis II. against the Retennu or Syrians. This shows for the first time the group of the chariot-borne Pharaoh smiting his enemies, which was later made into a conventional type by Amenophis IIIn Seta I., and Rameses II. There are also a geographical list of the same king’s victories a well-preserved and beautiful group in blank granite of Thothmes IV. and Queen Tia ; and a series of bas-reliefs from Amenophis IV.'s Temple of National Bank of Egypt. General Aten, which last are said to be important. All are going to the museum at Kasrel-NiL.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: (Vendredi, après-midi)

Les hauts prix atteints dernièrement ont donné lien à de fortes réalisations de la part des capitalistes et des marchés européens qui étaient abondamment pourvus de titres égyptiens. Il en est résulté ici un tassement. Les petits spéculateurs surtout ont vu leurs posi tions surchargées, à tel point qu’une réaction était inévitable. Elle s’est produite cette semaine, mais elle a été. de peu d’importance.On a parlé à ce propos d’une tension monétaire qui sévirait sur notre place ; mais c’est là un bruit dénué de tout fondement. C’est plutôt le contraire qui est vrai.
Les valeurs les plus en vogue cette semaine ont été la Banque Nationale, l’Agricole, la Daïra, l’Egyptian Investment et la Salt & Soda.

Bien que le dividende soit au-dessous de ce qu'on espérait cette année, l’avenir de la Banque se présente sous les meilleurs auspices et justifie pleinement la hausse des cours. On débute à 27 1/2, fléchit à 27 1/16 et reprend en clôture à 27 1/4.

Très ferme d’abord, la Daïra fléchit peu à peu sous la pression des réalisations et d’une vague rumeur suivant laquelle des princes de la famille khédiviale auraient l’intention d’attaquer la société pour vente de biens wakfs. Il va sans dire qu’il s’agit là d’une vague rumeur qui mérite confirmation et que le fait, fût-il exact, n aurait pas de conséquences graves pour la société, puisque celle-ci ne manquerait pas en ce cas d’en tenir responsable le gouvernement qui lui a accordé la concession des susdits terrains. S’il fallait en cruire les racontars, la Daïra liquiderait à 30 livres, mais nous croyons être plus proches de la vérité en fixant ce chiffre entre 28 et 29 livres. Le cours a débuté à 26, fléchi à 25 3/8 et repris eu clôture à 25 1/2.

L’Agricole reste toujours en faveur auprès du public, bien que la dividende de 6 shellings ait un peu déçu les capitalistes. Eu effet, l’augmentation croissante des affaires ,de cette société laisse entrevoir un dividende toujours plus élevé. La valeur debute à 11 1/2 pour clôturer à 11 1/4 ex coupon. Les parts de fondateur ont été pratiquées entré £ 730 et 745 mais en nombre excessivement restreint.

L’Egyptian Investment débute à 2 1/4, fié chit à 2 1/8, remonte ensuite à 2 11/32 et clôture enfin à 2 1/4, prix d’ouverture. Il parait que 1a société a en vue plusieurs affaires auxquelles le marché réserverait un bon accueil. On parle même da lancement d’une banque de report au capital de £ 1.000.000. Le chiffre des transactions est énorme : plusieurs milliers de titres par jour. Les actions n’étant pas encore sorties, les spéculateurs en profitent pour travailler sur de gros paquets et vendre et acheter aussitôt qu’une fluctuation favorable se produit.

On fait circuler la rumeur d’un dividende satisfaisant pour les actionnaires de la Sait and Soda. Aussi l’animation reprend-elle sur cette valeur ; le nombre des transactions a été considérable cette semaine. Le prix a ouvert à 41/9, baissé à 40/6, remonté à 42/1 1 /2 pour clôturer à 41/9.

Les Tramways d Alexandrie étaient tout-à-fait délaissés au début à 146. Peu après, cependant, une reprise a eu lien à 147 1/2, avec beaucoup d’animation. On clôture à 147. Les dividendes ont fluctué entre 355 et 360 et clôturé à 358.
La Delta Light, qui était également délaissée d’abord à 14 3/16, reprend à 141/2. La Société, parait-il, chercherait à obtenir du Gouvernement l’autorisation d’émettre 350,000 £. d'obligations 4 %.
La Béhéra fluctue entre 50 1/2 et 51 1/2 pour clôturer à 50 1/2 nominal.
La Ramleh Railway demeure faible toute la semaine à 8, prix auquel elle clôture offerte.
Calme aussi la Banque d’Athènes entre 120 et 121 1/2. Elle clôture à 121.
La Nungovich ouvre à 10 7/8 pour retomber à 10 1/2 ; la tendance, toutefois, reste bonne.
L’Anglo American Nile reste stationnaire à 5 5/8- et les Markets à 23/9.
L'animation a bien diminué en Oasis. Le cours débute à 1 9/32, atteint 1 3/8, mais retombe en clôture à 1 1/8.
On a traité la New Egyptian Cy. entre 37/6 et 38/6 ; on a clôturé à 37/9.

En résumé, si l’on peut s’attendre à ce que la réaction s’accentue encore légèrement, l’ensemble du marché n’en est pas moins excellent et la situation complètement saine. La baisse provient en partie d’anciennes positions pour échéances qui ont été liquidées fin février.
(Aujourd'hui à midi et demie)
Le marché reste à peu près sans changement.
Il y a baisse, pourtant, en Agricole à 11 5/16, en Banque d’Athènes à 120 1/2, en Daïra à 25 7/16, en Sait and Soda à 41/9, en Delta à 14 3/8 et en Ramleh Railway à 7 15/16.
Il y a hausse, au contraire, de la Wardan à 7 3/8, des Markets à 24 et del’Anglo-American Nile à 5 11/16.
Les affaires font défaut.

div.head: Gratuitement
div.p: Le succès très vit a toujours fait noble escorte à cet admirable procédé d’enseignement rapide et pratique : la méthode Berlitz qui permet en un temps si court de connaître n’importe quelle langue vivante : français, anglais, allemand, arabe, italien etc. etc.

On peut gratuitement se rendre compte de la méthode en prenant une leçon d’essai et en demandant des renseignements aux succursales de l’Institut Berlitz en Egypte : au Caire N° 1 Charia Camel, à Alexandrie 26 rue de l’Eglise Copte. 25524-1

div.head: Un Bon Dictionnaire
div.p: MM. Clifton et J. McLauglin viennent de publier une nouvelle édition de leur dictionnaire, dont les deux parties, français-anglais et anglais-français, sont reliées en un seul volume La facture en est élégante et solide : il contient tout le vocabulaire de la langue usuelle et donne, outre les mots nouveaux, un grand nombre de termes scientifiques, techniques et commerciaux, ainsi que la prononciation figurée de tous les mots. Cet ouvrage, qui se recommande à tous les points de vue, est édité par Garnier Frères, 6, rue des Saint-Pères, Paris.

div.head: Municipalité d’Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication 60 bancs et 40 chaises pour jardins en pitch pine ou Suède.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 20.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau du Nettoiement où il peut être consulté par la-; intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l’Administrateur de la Mu nicipalité avant le 21 Mars 1905.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h.p.m
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la men tion ‘‘Soumission pour Bancs et Chaises.”
Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges. devra être remis à la Comptabilité Générale avant l’ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 21 Mars à midi.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: Khedivial Yacht Club.
REPORT FOR 1904.
The following is the text of the report of the K.Y.C. committee for 1904 :—
Gentlemen, Your Committee beg to present to you the third annual report of the working of the Khédivial Yacht Club.
A general meeting was held on February 16th, 1904, when the accounts for 1903 were passed and the Committee and officers elected for the year.
A fair trial of one year’s duration has now been given to the new Club House and has proved beyond a doubt that it is successful in every way.

The number of new members who have join ed is 47, bringing the total number of members up to 156 as against 109 in 1903 ; the entrance fees of these new members, as shown by the balance sheet, amounts to L. E. 97, which is practically the balance L.E. 102 we have in hand to carry forward to the current year.

Under the heading of “ Furniture etc. ” L.E. 77.760 m m has been spent; this includes sufficient chairs and tables and tea-cups, etc., to render the Club capable of entertaining the maximum number of persons (about 200) it can accommodate on any special occasion without having to resort to hiring or borrowing.

Now that the Club is put on a firm footing and the colours of the flag have been definitely settled, the House Committee have taken in hand the designing of a suitable blazer and the settling of the Club colours, hence the large expenditure of L.E. 21.847 m/m. as against receipts L.E. 12.555 m/m under head ing of “hat ribbons etc.,” but this leaves a quantity of these materials in hand. and next year we reckon that the receipts under this head will be more than the expenditure.

With reference to the large item of L.E. 85.250 m/m. for repairs, etc., this includes several large repairs which were absolutely necessary, such as replastering the roof, which has leaked badly and injured the ceilings, which have also had to be repaired ; the masonry’ steps also on the sea side have needed constant overhauling due to the bank subsid ing. The starters kiosk has also been altered and the mast has been put on the harbour side ol the same ; this year a lower-mast is being added and the old mast used as a top mast to render the starting flags more con spicuous, as a difficulty was experienced in picking them out when several large boats flying their distinguishing Hugs were near the mast. Two auxiliary landings for small boats have been added on the jetty, also a dressing room under the starter’s kiosk.

A proposal was put before the General Com mittee on December 19th that a boat shed and slip, which is badly needed for hauling up the members' boats, be built in the Arsenal, the cost being estimated at L.E. 100, but this was rejected as costing too much ; instead it was decided to build entrance doors and windows on the North side of the corridor of the Club at a cost of L.E. 30, and this is now being done.
The buffet has easily covered expenses, its receipts exceeding its expenditure by L.E. 21.010 m/m.
Presentation cups and prizes have cost approximately L.E. 45 and this sum has been expended mostly in gold and silver jewellery, enamelled to order with the club burgee.

A new system of awarding the prizes was instituted, viz., that of giving points for three consecutive races only, and a prize given to the boat which scored the highest number of points in each set of three races; The old system of dividing the boats into two classes was still maintained.
Suggestions are invited from members as to the best way of awarding prizes for the current year.
Of the L. E. 35.490 m/m. for “extra wages” most of it has been expended on auxiliary waiters on regatta days.

The number of regattas held during the year was 23 and the average number of boats sailing in the same was 12; they were handicapped according to results, and the handicaps were eventually adjusted so finely that in the regatta of August 31st 5 boats crossed the finishing line within 65 seconds, and in the regatta of September 14th 6 boats within 2 3/4 minutes.

His Highness Prince Aziz on March 15th, as Commodore, on behalf of the Club, challeng ed the Delta Barrage Bailing Club to race his ,one-rater “Haddayah” against their best one-rater, which was the “Isis,” the stakes to be (euro)5 a-side the boats to be handicapped on rating and to sail three races on the Nile at Cairo. On this being done the “Haddayah” won easily.
On June 1st His Highness gave a cup to each class for the best boat handicapped on rating only. Class 1 was won by the “Hans” and Class 2 was won by the “Cattelaya. ”

On July 27th an “At Home” was given by the Club in honour of the visit of the British Fleet, a cup being given for a sailing race for the officers, which was won by the whaler of H.B.M.S. “Surprise;” there were no less than 65 boats started ; there was also a pulling race for the men which was won by the 14-oared cutter of H. B. M. S. “Prince of Wales,” each man of which was awarded a money prize of half a sovereign.
The Commodore’s challenge cups were raced for on September 7th and won as follows : Class 1, Air. McClure in the “Jenny. ” Class 2, Sagh. Phillips in the “ Akraba.”
A. Chitty Bey very kindly gave a prize which was raced for and won by Captain Arbuthnot in the “Shamrock,” who scored the highest number of points out of three races.

At the special regatta on October 26th given in honour of the race for the Challenge Cup of His Highness the Khedive the “ Masr ” won on her time allowance, as it was such a calm day that the boats could only complete one round. Each holder of the cup, from the time of its institution as a challenge cup, has been awarded a pretty miniature of the same, and these will continue to be awarded yearly.

On the occasion of the visit of the Greek Squadron an “ At Home ” was given by the Club to the officers of the Fleet which was a great success ; a cup was given for a race between the Club boats of Class 2 which was won by the “ Tantah ” ; and a pulling race which was won by a 12-oared cutter of the H.H.M.S. Hydra, the coxswain of which elected to have a silver plate engraved and enamelled with the design of the Club burgee which will he affixed to the bows of the winning boat. The prizes were awarded by Madame Benachi, wife of the President of the Greek colony at Alexandria, at the request of the Vice-Commodore.
This regatta concluded the season’s racing.

For the providing of the two “At Homes ” given to the Fleets a subscription was got up amongst the members of the Club, and put into a special fund called the “Entertainment Fund.” This was so well responded to that there was a balance of L. E. 12,703 m/m. Out of this the silver plate for the Greek Fleet prize will be paid, value L.E. 4.500 m/m. It has been ordered from Europe ; when it arrives it will be sent on to the winner. The Committee gratefully acknowledge the kind assistance rendered and facilities offered by the officials of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration, also the kindness of the members of the Alexandria Municipality, who have voted the Club a yearly grant of L. E. 50, besides repairing the road and approaches to the Club House

It has been decided that for the future the Sailing Rules of the Yacht Racing Association shall be adopted as the Club’s Sailing Rules, and additions to these rules, found necessary, will he appended to the General and Club House Rules.

Any member wishing to make any proposal as to alterations or modifications to the Rules and Regulations is requested to do so in writing to the Honorary Secretary before the General Meeting giving the names of Proposer and Seconder.

div.head: BRITISH RIFLE CLUB, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: REPORT OF COMMITTEE.
The following is the text of the report of the committee of the B. R. C., Alexandria, for 1904:-
The Committee now beg to present their report on the working of the Club during the fifth year of its existence.

Unfortunately, the number of members, which had increased to 94 in 1903-4, fell off again last season to a total of 77, composed of 49 ordinary members and 28 from the Staff of. the Eastern Telegraph Coy., Ltd.
Notwithstanding this smaller total, the number of members who made use of the range was well maintained and a higher standard of efficiency in marksmanship was attained.

The G. O. C. and the Head Quarter Staff of H.M.’s forces at Alexandria, as well as Col McCracken and Officers of the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regt., have again earned the thanks of the Club for their unvarying kind assistance. Among other facilities granted by them, members were enabled, last summer, to practise on the long ranges at Mex.

Of the 7 matches which the Club had the pleasure of shooting against teams from various units of H. M.s Army and Navyv our team won 4 and lost 3. The usual match with the Cairo B.R.C. could not, unfortunately, be an ranged.

The Competitions for Mr. Allen’s spoons were, as heretofore, an additional means of keeping up interest in the shooting, for which we have again to thank that gentleman. The winners of the spoons were, in Class I., Messrs. W. B. Carlisle, W. Lucas, P. Schilizzi (twice), C.W. Strickland and H. Waddington; in Class II., Messrs. S. A. Betts, W. B. Carlisle, R. H. Plank and L.H. Rickards ; in Class III., Messrs. S. A. Betts, T. E. Brown, J. Gordon, IL W. Grant and R. H. Plank. Three spoons, not won, will be put up for competition again shortly.
The year’s Champion Cups were won in Class I. by Mr. W, Lucas and in Class 11. by Mr. W. B. Carlisle.

N.R.A. Skilled Shot” certificates were gain-ed during the season by 7 members, Mr. W. Lucas qualifying for the N.R.A. silver badge, by obtaining 10 such certificates, and the new N.R.A. “Rifleman ” certificate was granted to Messrs. S. A. Betts, S. E. Brown and R. H. Plank, the “Donegall ” bronze badge being won by Mr. P. Schilizzi.

Owing to the loss entailed by supplying ammunition to members at half its cost, and the small number of members subscribing, the funds of the Club are practically exhausted, as will be seen from the annexed statement of accounts, and it will be a question for the Committee to consider means to replenish the drain upon its resources. It is probable that any increase in the amount of subscription would result in a falling off in the membership, and the Committee, therefore, feel that they have no alternative hut to suggest raising the price at which ammunition is sold on the range.

The Committee would point out that the benefits of the Club are not confined to permanent residents only, hut are extended also to a considerable number of those who are only here temporarily, and who are continually being replaced by new arrivals.

Owing to the range at Mustapha being closed for repairs at the end of October last, our shooting season then terminated, which was about a month earlier than usual, and, consequently, not as much shooting could begot through.

The duties of Hon. Treasurer, Hon. Secretary, and joint Hon. Secretary, were performed by Messrs H.F. Dickson, P. Schilizzi and A. S. Preston, respectively, and the Committee again beg to acknowledge, with thanks, the assistance of these gentlemen, as well as of their president, Mr. F. Allen.
